I actually saw Avengers on its opening night a couple of weeks ago. I'm dying to go see it again! It's rare for a much-hyped movie to actually live up to its hype, but I think it's actually the case here. It's amazing what can happen when you put an actual writer on one of these blockbuster smashes.

I'm not sure how anyone can beat Ironman (who has the most screen time, the best quips, and just about any AC/DC song you can think of as his personal entrance music), but the movie did a great job of showcasing everybody (with the possible exception of Thor, who still had a great one-liner just for good measure).

Still, as much as I like Robert Downey, Jr. as Tony Stark, my favorite line from the movie had to be from Cap: "All right, listen up! Until we can close that portal up there, what we need is containment. Barton: I want you on that roof, eyes on everything. Call out patterns and strays. Stark: you've got the perimeter. Anything gets more than three blocks out, you turn it back or you turn it to ash. Thor: you've gotta try and bottleneck that portal, slow them down. You've got the lightning - light the bastards up! [Turns to Black Widow] You and me: we stay here on the ground, keep the fighting here. And Hulk: smash!

It's time for me to really get back to writing, and that means posting here somewhat more regularly.

I do have some great news! I already have a contract for next year at the same great place I'm teaching this year. I'm even going to be teaching 2nd graders again, so I already have a solid start. This year has been so awesome, and I'm pretty fired up about some of the stuff I'm going to be adding in the coming year. Now, if the end of the year testing (which begins next week) is as good for my current class as I'm expecting, this year will truly be one of the best years of my life. I am scheduled to take a two week class in June (where they are actually paying me to take it, is that crazy or what?), but the rest of my summer is looking pretty free.



On to other stuff...

What I'm Writing: I'm in the early stages of an adventure for "Sex, Lies and Ultraspies", which I'm calling "Hunter's Island". I'm still trying to figure out the exact format of the thing, but in general I want it to be an adventure/villain/bestiary sourcebook. I've got some great ideas, the only real problem I'm experiencing (other than sitting down and typing away at it) is working in some hints of future products. I'm also initially working in Word instead of Googledocs, which is improving my output significantly over "Spy Racers". I vow that this will not take two years to get out! After "Hunter's Island", I will move on to "Submariners", my underwater sourcebook for "Sex, Lies and Ultraspies."

Other Stuff: Believe it or not, GenCon is right around the corner. The events listing is up and event registration is nearly upon us. I'm going to be running three events, all of them on Saturday and all of them "Sex, Lies and Ultraspies" related. I've got some great ideas for all three. For the traditional Ministry Q event, I'm planning on hacking the plot from the pathetic "Devil May Care" James Bond novel into something with Ultraspy goodness. The villain in that work has ape-like hands, where my villain will have ape-like arms! I'm going to be doing a Speed Racer episode retread for "Submariners". I'm also introducing a new event for "Agents of DEAD", which is my take on the darker side of the '60s (a la Twilight Zone and Outer Limits). I'm pretty sure the adventure is going to have something to do with zombies (but my own special take on zombies, which will kick the living crap out of the traditional Romero ones). This one is going to take the most work, since I need characters and background writeups.

What I'm Reading: I have become enamored of a "Young Readers" author by the name of Matthew Cody. On a whim at my daughter's book sale, I picked up his novel called "Powerless", and discovered he had a seriously great take on the superhero genre. I recently bought his book "The Dead Gentleman", which is his take on Steam Punk/Time Travel.  While I love the main characters (including a hella scary villain) and the setting, the plot is a little too much "stuff happening to the characters" rather than "characters making stuff happen". Still, for some absolutely marvelous gaming ideas, it's hard to go wrong with some of the stuff being produced by authors in the "Young Readers" (Grades 5-7) category.

What I'm Watching: I finally got into the more recent Doctor Who stuff on Netflix, and burned through about six years worth of stuff in a little over a month. This is truly amazing for me to say, but I think that David Tennant is the best Doctor Who ever (even if the end of his run was fairly weak). The saying is that your favorite Doctor is the one you grew up with, and for the longest time I would tell you that Tom Baker was the Doctor for me. Now, I'm looking to get into another scifi series on Netflix. I'm trying Farscape, but it's been pretty slow going at the beginning.

Other than that, my family is outstanding. My wife has started working in a new area at her hospital. My oldest daughter scored a 31 on her ACTs and is looking at colleges (She's a high school senior next year). My youngest daughter is set to become the ruling class at her school, moving into the 6th grade. My cat is awesome and currently curled up and purring at my side. I've inherited two of the cutest guinea pigs you have ever seen as class pets. Life is pretty darn good.

Okay, it's been quite a while since I posted here. Maybe we should start with a general update.


Last April, I got some bad news. The charter school where I was teaching was not going to be offering me a contract for the next school year.  The official line was "behavior management concerns", although that didn't seem to make sense to almost anyone with whom I had worked. This was particularly baffling considering I had made 100% of the bonuses they had set up based on student scores and teaching observations.

Still, I decided I would make the best of it. The good news was that the teaching job market was way better than the previous year, with many, many more opportunities. I had 3 interviews, but unfortunately I had no response from any of them by the time the new school year was about to get underway.

I decided to go with substitute teaching (which I had pretty much expected to be doing a year earlier anyway). I went with a service that provided substitutes for charter schools across the cities. We had used them at my previous charter school. At first, it was very slow. I only got four placements in my first two weeks.

Having time to sit around and think about my situation was not a good thing. Before it was over, I had signed up as a substitute for three nearby districts, applied for a job at a local convenience store chain, and even visited one of those day labor places.

Everything started rolling along after that. I found substitute teaching to be pretty fun, once you got beyond the mad scramble, wait to see if anyone needs you, walk into the unknown part of the job. I made a couple of great connections at charter schools at which I wouldn't mind eventually working. Teachers were starting to request me. Also, I did get that convenience store job over the weekend to help supplement any shortfalls I might have had during the week in addition to the times I knew I wouldn't be working (holiday and summers).

Then, a fateful Wednesday in mid-October happened.  I came home from what had been a pretty terrible 3rd grade class, probably my worse substitute assignment to date (and they were actually happy with my performance, but more on that later). I noticed on my caller ID that a friend and co worker from my previous charter school had called me. She had moved on to a different charter school in the area, and we had briefly talked and exchanged some files we had worked on together the previous year. She hadn't left a message, but since she had just tried calling me 5 minutes before, I decided I would give her a call back.

"Are you still looking for a job?" she asked. "Submit your resume to this email address now." I quickly did it and almost immediately got a call back from her principal, asking if I would like to substitute teach at their school for the next two days with the possibility of being brought in permanently.

Now I had already set up something at my youngest daughter's school for the next day, but with the possibility of permanent work, I would have to cancel it (at the risk of being blacklisted there!). Somewhere in the flurry of calls between the principal, my previous co-worker, and my daughter's school, I got a call from the teacher I had been a substitute for that day (remember the bad third grade class?) wondering if I could fill in for her again because she had pneumonia (I had to tell her sorry but no).

So, what was going on at this charter school suddenly in desperate need of a teacher? Apparently, they were bringing in my previous co-worker to the kindergarten class to model classroom management for that teacher (she is one of the best teachers I've ever seen at handling urban students) when the kindergarten teacher decided she had enough and just quit.

Now, they wanted my co-worker to take over the supposedly rowdy kindergarten, and they would bring someone for her well-behaved second graders. She made a strong recommendation for me. I came in and substitute taught for two days, was offered a contract for the rest of the year that Friday, and the rest is history.

I am now the teacher of an absolutely fabulous group of second graders (already broken in very nicely by my previous and once again current co-worker). I even inherited two class guinea pigs!

The only problem I have in my life right now is that I'm still working at that convenience store over the weekends. The work is easy and I feel a strange sense of loyalty to them, so I haven't been able to bring myself to quit there, but it does sometimes make for working many days in a row (my record so far has been 21 straight days after Black Friday).

The next writing project I am working on is called "Racing Spies." I originally intended it to be something of a supplement/brand new thing dealing with '60s spies for QAGS, much along the lines of "Sex, Lies and Ultraspies." Since that initial conception, however, some things have changed.

First, a big chunk of "Sex, Lies and Ultraspies" got cut. Specifically, it was the vehicle and chase rules. Conveniently enough, that is exactly the same grounds I planned on covering for "Racing Spies," just more geared towards racing and spies of course.

Second, Hex Games released a product called "Cops and Robbers," which also covered vehicle and chase rules. I based my own vehicle and chase rules on a previous Hex Games product called "Rocket Jocks." Unfortunately, the rules in "Cops and Robbers" differed fairly significantly from these, and I feel I should adapt what I have done to better match "Cops and Robbers."

Third, and finally, I've taken a good hard look at the racing spy genre itself, mostly at its general popularity. My "Racing Spies" convention events are generally the most poorly attended ones that I run. The Wachowski brothers made a reasonably decent film about Speed Racer and it bombed. The undeniable truth of the matter is no matter how infatuated I am with Speed Racer and Racer X in particular, it has a fairly limited audience appeal (and it didn't even cost me $120 million dollars to figure that out like the Wachowskis).

I really want my follow up to "Sex, Lies and Ultraspies" to be successful. So, I have decided to focus "Racing Spies" less on the the racing spy stuff and treat it much more as a Vehicle and Chase supplement for "Sex, Lies and Ultraspies." Keeping this in mind, I'm going to simplify  and align the vehicle design rules more in accordance with "Cops and Robbers". I'm going to simplify the chase rules to some extent (while still keeping all those nifty chase tables). I'm going to present organizations and an adventure that the Ultraspies from "Sex, Lies and Ultraspies" will be more than comfortable participating in.

I've really been debating how to get myself fired up to get back to writing "Racing Spies," and I think I'm starting to figure it out.

Well, since I've updated my livejournal about my life, I might as well start updating about my writing and gaming.

Last August, Hex Games released Sex, Lies and Ultraspies in .pdf format (you can find it here). It has apparently generated decent enough sales (It was the hottest item for Hex Games on rpgnow until recently getting supplanted by their Frat Boys Vs. game. Of course, I don't think it ever got above 12th on their sister drivethrurpg site, but go figure.) It has also received some favorable buzz on Hex Games forums. I'm anxiously awaiting the first official review for it.

In a perfect world, I would have used this livejournal to post a type of Designer Notes for Sex, Lies and Ultraspies immediately or very soon after it was released. I enjoy reading this type of thing (just as an insight into what the author is thinking), but I can also understand those who are completely uninterested and are put off by having to pay for something like it (when it is included in the actual product). Posting it online would seem to offer the best of both worlds.

Since I couldn't get it done in a timely manner, this will have to suffice.

Sex, Lies and Ultraspies is something I was born to write. I know, I know, you were probably born to write anything you've actually wrote. Still, I feel uniquely qualified to have done Sex, Lies and Ultraspies. You see, I'm a '60s spy fanatic. While I'm too young to have watched it first hand on television and the movies, I definitely caught the reruns. One of the first movies I can remember watching on TV was James Bond's Thunderball. In high school, I was obsessed with The Avengers, catching it whenever I could in reruns. Later, I even collected the entire VHS collection of the Emma Peel years, and a good smattering of the Cathy Gale and Tara King episodes.

As far as roleplaying games are concerned, the very first one that I owned was Top Secret (although I did hear about D&D first). I was never into the fantasy genre (I could barely make it through The Hobbit, forget about Lord of the Rings). Of course, I collected the entire 007 Roleplaying Game line. Spycraft was even the game that eventually made me decide to purchase 3rd Edition D&D.

One of the things I've noticed with the more recent roleplaying games about spies was a tendency to fall into one of two traps.

The first is what I call the Cold War trap. The Cold War between the United States and Soviet Union was a dominant political and social force during the '60s. It's all too easy to assume '60s spies would be directly concerned with that aspect as well. I almost fell into this trap while I was writing Sex, Lies and Ultraspies myself. In looking back at the genre, however, '60s spies tried their best to avoid dealing with the Cold War at all. The threats tended to be shadowy organizations, often led by individuals with Eastern European accents, but never coming right out and claiming sides.

In order to have Sex, Lies and Ultraspies avoid the Cold War and better emulate the genre, I created an incident and a truce between the two sides of the Cold War. I'm definitely planning on focusing on Cold War anxiety in a future supplement.

The second trap is what I will call the Austin Powers trap, since that character is the most recent and familiar of the '60s spy farces to have come along. For some reason, the spy genre makes for excellent farce. For one thing, I believe because it is so rooted in our own real world, the spy genre can always dial back up to more seriousness and reality.

To give a better example, I have a hard time watching any western and seeing cowboys sitting around a campfire and not think about the scene from Blazing Saddles, no matter how serious the movie is trying to be. Blazing Saddles has seriously impacted my ability to watch any western with a serious mind. On the other hand, watching James Bond talk into a miniature radio doesn't necessarily always make me think of Maxwell Smart talking into his shoe. I would argue that spy farces have been among the most successful of any genre farce in history. You have Matt Helm, Derek Flint, Maxwell Smart, and Austin Powers are prime exhibits.

Still, for the most part '60s spies were meant to be reasonably serious, with an occasional foray into wit and amusement. Again, there are certainly enough counter examples that I am strongly considering doing a farce supplement for Sex, Lies and Ultraspies in the future as well.

As far as actual game design is concerned, my main philosophy is to keep things as simple as possible. I have really grown to appreciate the QAGS system. I've been a fan of too many other systems (Champions and BESM come to mind) that became bloated an ultra complicated. Any rule I introduced I wanted to make sure that there was an easier, if less structured, way to do it as well. So, I came up with the easy way, and the slightly more complex way, and it seems to have been accepted by QAGS fans.

Next up, I plan on completing Racing Spies, a supplement for Sex, Lies and Ultraspies. I write more about where I'm headed with that product next.

Long time, no post. Well, I might as well update my life situation at this point.

For anyone that missed the references in my GenCon postings, I did get a job as a first grade teacher at a charter school in Minneapolis. That job started right away in August, and has kept me pretty busy since then. One of the philosophies of this particular charter school is longer school days (the actual school day goes from 8:30 to 5, I'm usually in by 7:30) and a longer school year (we started classes in mid-August and will go to the first day in July, effectively making us year round).

So far, I've found teaching to be a tiring but definitely worthwhile endeavor. My class is almost looking like what I would consider a first grade class should look like, and we've started getting a lot of compliments from onlookers. I've felt very well supported by my administration (I have a wonderful, highly experienced teacher's assistant in addition to a paraprofessional for one of my students, and there have been numerous suspensions which seem to have proven the point to most of my class that I'm the one in charge).

And yes, the days are very long and the pressure to perform is great (For example, I will give my first graders four quizzes tomorrow, one spelling, one timed computational math, one conceptual math, and one language arts. This is pretty much the drill every week except when we do the bigger unit tests, which begin next week. Remember this is first grade!). Still, I really don't think it's any greater than what I came from in the corporate retail world (and so much more fulfilling for me). Even though I work longer hours and more days than regular school teachers, I still remind myself that I get 9+ weeks of vacation (one week at Thanksgiving, two weeks at Christmas, one week at Easter, four weeks in July, and five Paid Time Off days, plus all of the regular holidays). I've never worked at a job before where I had more than three. I also have almost every night free with my family.

So, I'm slowly but surely getting a grip on this teaching thing. I've decided to get back to posting to my livejournal because I find it's a good way to get me started writing, and I'm comfortable enough where I'm at in my new profession to spend a little time writing. So, more to come. First up, where I've been in writing games.

After all my preparations for GenCon to try and make sure whoever is running the events I signed up for (and cannot make) go extremely well, I've had some gaming burnout. I was planning on going to Mage-Con in Sioux City over Labor Day weekend (and this year, I'll actually be able to attend a larger chunk of it since I'm not working retail anymore). Usually, I run a miniature war game event, but after all of the work I put in for GenCon (even when I'm not going to be there), I was feeling pretty burned out. I figured I would go just as a player this year, since they seem to need more players than gamemasters anyhow.

In talking with my brother-in-law last night, he managed to convince me otherwise. So, I'm going to not only run my AK47 Republic stuff in Modern Africa, but I'm also going to try a role playing event for the first time there (Jawgrinder, which I already have prepared conveniently enough from GenCon). Hopefully, his enthusiasm will transfer over to me sometime during this month.

I've really been in a "Jawgrinder" kind of mode lately. I've become obsessed with the so-called "Iron Age" of comic books, particularly its most notorious artist (and I guess you could call him a writer as well). I've picked up two superhero book collections recently: X-Force Cable: The Legend Returns and X-Force Shatterstar.

The first is a collection from when Marvel apparently welcomed Mr. Liefeld back to try and revive a book (X-Force) that they had pretty much destroyed. It is absolutely what I expected, which is that wacky meant-to-be-serious-but-absolutely-hysterical combination of in your face graphics and absurd storyline. Everybody talks tough and fights a lot (even each other). In the book, Cable returns and collects a motley "team" to battle the most vicious threat to mutant kind that nobody had ever heard of before or since, an alien with the wonderfully misspelled name of  Skornn. Domino starts the story off, then a future version of herself makes an appearance dressed up as the supervillain Stryfe in a homoerotic wet dream kind of way, ending with the original (or was it the future self, I'm so confused). The Shi'Ar Imperial Guard check up on things just so Rob can draw some cool looking spaceships. Deadpool makes an appearance for no apparent reason other than to say that he was there. Fantastic stuff!

The second book starts off with a story which leads up to the first book, where Shatterstar, the what-the-hell-are-you-doing-hanging-around-with-mutants-pretending-you're-one-of-them-when-your-really-a-genetically-enhanced-freak-from-another-dimension warrior, must fight to obtain the weapon which will eventually destroy Skornn (but not really). Unfortunately, the artwork is not by Mr. Liefeld, so it's not nearly as good (in a bad way). He is listed as the "plotter" of the story, so I'm guessing he must have explained his vision to someone who tried to hammer it into something sensible. It's okay, but I wouldn't have wasted my money on it for that part. The really fantastic part of the book is in the last half, which features the last three episodes of The New Mutants before X-Force was launched. Of course, these are all done by Mr. Liefeld, and are incredible (if you are as obsessed as I am). It's like the start of a super hero roleplaying game where you have to somehow mash everyone's individual story lines into some kind of cohesion, and don't quite succeed that makes any sense, but at least everyone is together and fighting things (including each other). Shatterstar and Feral make their first appearance, replacing Rictor and Sunspot on the team, and there's that glorious moment where Stryfe reveals himself to be Cable at the very end. I was almost squealing with joy at the memories of my misspent youth!

To continue with my GenCon teasers, here are a couple of character sheets for "Jawgrinder". Notice how the Numbers you need to input (from the five cards you drew) are conveniently highlighted on the sheet (as they are on the card). I'm hoping this will make things absolutely clear, but gamers being gamers, I'm sure there will still be some confusion.





As you can see, I included character artwork outlines on the character sheets. One of the most fun things for us with the original Champions was coloring up our characters, so this is a tribute to that (and ever the overacheiver, I have something like 15 different male poses and 10 different female poses).

I'm particularly pleased with the well-armed Happy D20 in the upper left (and he naturally has a "Jawgrinder" sort of pose).

Well, for those who may not know, I got good news and bad news recently. The good news is that I have been hired as a teacher for this coming school year. The bad news is that I start my duties right away in August, so I will not be able to attend GenCon this year. This will be the first time I have not gone to GenCon in 23 years!

This caused a mad scramble to try and get someone to run my four spots for Hex Games (which they did). I also felt obligated to put together some pretty concrete material for this nice person, so I've been hammering away at that for a few weeks now. I'd thought I'd post some of the stuff I've put together just for a teaser. Here's the first one:


This is a sheet from my "Jawgrinder" game. "Jawgrinder" is basically my tribute to a particular artist from the so-called "Modern Age" of superhero comic books. Players will design their own "kewl" superheroes using the QAGS system. Each player will randomly pick five different cards (from 80 different ones, this is only nine of them). As you can see, each card has a number (which will be used for the stats) and some ideas regarding Names, Jobs, Gimmicks, and Weaknesses. I really like the way they turned out, and I hope these cards not only make character creation super easy, but evoke the spirit and mood I'm shooting for in this adventure. Obviously, I gave this artist's better known character creations a higher Number, and the words may or may not have much at all to do with the character depicted on the card.

For Father's Day, my family got me the book "Ironman, the Ultimate Guide to the Armored Superhero." They know me so well! In looking it over, I've made three observations:

1.  I'm thinking I should be following what Matt Fraction writes more closely. After reading his Foreward in the book, I was struck by how similar some of our brainwaves must be (he even writes about the theme song from the '60s "animated" television show). I think Fraction "gets" Ironman (his conclusion that Ironman is one of the few superheroes whose alter ego--Tony Stark--is as much, if not more, fun being up front and center stage is spot on). After checking out his work on Casanova, I think Fraction also "gets" '60s superspies as well (it's not about Jack Bauer capping some guy's kneecaps down at the 7/11, although Fraction certainly does like to throw in a bunch of tangential and just plain weird stuff). I might have to check out some of his current Ironman comics, as well as the Mighty Thor (which will be a challenge for me, since I've never been a big fan of the blonde haired Norse wonder).

2. Ironman has become the center of the Marvel Universe. I used to think it was Spiderman, and I supposed a strong argument could still be made for him. Still, it seems like Spidey is often on the fringes of so many of Marvel's big storylines, while Ironman is right smack dab in the middle of them (even the whole House of M thing, which surprised me as I was reading the book).

3. Marvel's character bullpen is so much deeper and wider than DC's that it's scary. I know these are fighting words, but after Batman, I have a hard time caring much about any other DC character (although I can appreciate Superman's significance). Then you move on to what? Green Lantern? Wonder Woman? Flash? Green Arrow? (Okay, I like Flash when he's not being comedic relief.) I'm saddened to say this because I was a big DC fan during "Crisis," but returned to Marvel shortly afterwards when not a lot seemed to be happening in DC-land (and moved on from there when "way too much to comprehend" seemed to be happening in the Marvel-verse). All in all, I can easily be interested in about 10 different major Marvel superheroes (Ironman, Spiderman, Wolverine, Hulk, Captain America, the Fantastic Four, Daredevil, Silver Surfer, Punisher, Thor, and I can even get intrigued by some minor ones too, Moon Knight anyone?).

I was hunting through the DVD section of my warehouse sales the other day after I noticed one member had purchased the movie "Sideways" for only $4.99. One of my coworkers is always talking about this movie (which is apparently wine related so comes up fairly frequently when working in the liquor department) and I thought I should check it out at some point.

In true warehouse sales fashion, I couldn't find "Sideways" anywhere, but I did find and buy the complete collection of four Matt Helm movies for only $12.99. These are campy spy parodies from the '60s starring Dean Martin. I've watched three of them now ("The Silencers", "Murderer's Row", and "The Ambushers"). I think they're almost better now than they were back in the '60s, as they have a lot of '60s panache (Mike Myers owes these movies a significant royalty for all the stuff that he stole in Austin Powers). 

Helm has three signature moves that have turned up in every movie so far. He drinks a lot (often while driving), he strips the clothes off from women (sometimes accidentally, sometimes not), and he's always armed with at least one quirky gun (i.e. fires backwards, freezes target, takes ten seconds before going off, fires an anti-gravity beam). What's not fun about that?

I was almost thrown for a loop when I saw the Producer of these movies was Irving Allen. I thought "Is this the guy that did 'Voyage to the Bottom of the Sea', 'Lost In Space', 'Land of the Giants', and 'Time Tunnel'?" Nope, as it turns out, that was actually Irwin Allen (no relation apparently).

Also, I saw "Iron Man 2" on its opening weekend. It was fantastic, 'nuff said!

I thought I would drop by the GenCon website to see how my events were faring. Here's how they look so far as pre-registration is concerned:

Sex, Lies and Ultraspies--8 tickets sold, no tickets left (this event selling out is not a big surprise given the provocative name and the extensive fan base that has been building at GenCon for about five years now);

Submariners--4 tickets sold, 4 left (this event also seems to be gaining some traction with some of the regular GenCon attendees);

Racing Spies--2 tickets sold, 6 left (this event has always been problematic and I'm not sure why);

Jawgrinder--no tickets sold, 8 left (this surprises me somewhat, since it seems GenCon attendees almost like superheroes better than fantasy adventurers, still it might be the obscure title causing problems).

I'm pretty happy that 14 people have laid down money so far to be in my events. The flip side of the coin is that pre-registration has almost nothing to do with who actually shows up to your event. It almost seems that getting sold out early is a bad thing, as that may mean some large group has decided to give your event a shot, but will collectively stand you up once they discover other stuff going on during the convention.

It's about time I get cranking on preparing my events.

I've been keeping busy lately, both in checking out DVDs and reading books.

I finally got around to watching Heroes Season 2. I've had it for a while, but the rumors were it was pretty bad, so I wasn't inspired to check it out until I got Heroes Season 3 for Christmas. The good news is that I don't think Season 2 was all that bad, and there were actually parts of it that I thought were fairly inspired. The bad news was that I thought the first half of Season 3 ("Villains") was pretty awful. Still, it picked up very nicely during the second half of the season ("Fugitives"). There are definitely times when I feel that Heroes writers just throw stuff in with no real purpose in mind (like the Eclipse and the B&W scenes from '61).

For reading material, I've been collecting more of the Alex Rider teen series. They read super fast and the writer is pretty good at action pacing. I have also been working through Pirates by Ted Bell, another novel which is supposed to have a James Bond-y feel to it. It's decent enough, although the author has some kind of grudge against the French (the big villain is France, seriously?) and gets little details wrong (China has the world's largest stockpile of nuclear weapons, since when?). He also has a character that is so much of a caricature (of a big, scary black man) that it's almost uncomfortably racist (although the attempt is meant to be actually heroic and positive).

For comic books, I just picked up the Cable and the New Mutants collection, which should hopefully get me properly in the Rob Liefeld mindset just in time for my "Jawgrinder" event at GenCon in August.

There's also stuff I've been reading for school, but that's pretty dry and boring and best left undetailed.

Since it's been a while since I've posted, I figured it might be okay to bore everyone with the minutae of my existence.

--I begin student teaching next week. The light at the end of my life transition tunnel is fully in view. Only 13 weeks from now, I should have my teaching license (if all goes well). I'll be teaching first graders. I must be getting a rep, because I was teaching first graders during my literacy clinical last semester as well. I've already met my cooperating teacher and class, and that was a fantastic experience. After last semester, I was amazed to discover that it was possible to have the eyes of every first grader upon you, eagerly listening to your every word.

I recently finished the next in the "Union Trilogy" of James Bond novels by Raymond Benson. It was called "Doubleshot" and had a fairly standard doppelganger plot. You know, the one where the secret agent has an exact double about to commit some nefarious deed, only to be replaced by the actual secret agent who tricks the bad guys into thinking he or she is the double.

It's really standard fare in the spy genre, particularly on television shows. I can probably think of at least a half dozen variations of this theme covered in the Avengers, for example. Unfortunately, it doesn't really work in novel form (although I must admit "Point Blank" in the teen spy Alex Rider series was a variation on the "replacing important people with obedient doppelgangers" plot that didn't suck). Unfortunately, Benson writes next to nothing about the action surrounding the doppelganger, choosing to focus on Bond stumbling around from one plot point to the next. 

After suffering through this novel, I felt compelled to watch the Avengers' episode "They Keep Killing Steed" (One of the better Tara King efforts). One of the reasons doppelganger plots work so much better on television is that you actually see that the doppelganger looks just like his or her victim (because they are played by the same actor). If it's an actor as talented as Patrick Macnee, you can also tell by his basic mannerisms that, even though the doppelganger looks just like the main character, he is not actually John Steed. No wonder they kept going back to this plotline again and again.

I did have to laugh because the back cover promo for "Doubleshot" said that this adventure would take Bond to the "seedy" side of Soho. Basically, it meant that Bond visited an adult bookstore.

I'd like to take yet another episode of "I Spy" and "Ultraspy" it. This one was called "Father Abraham", and was about a young physicist who decides to sacrifice himself to feed the commies bad information and interfere with their solid rocket fuel program. Our two intrepid heroes, Kelly and Alexander, are directed to break him down, basically interrogate him until he spills the beans in a convincing enough manner.

They then escort him around Rome, with the backstory that he is a brilliant, but embittered and alcoholic American physicist responsible for a breakthrough in solid rocket fuel, hoping the enemy will take the bait. Unfortunately, the young physicist's father, a powerful and influential general, gets word of his son's shenanigans and confronts him about his unAmerican ways (he would rather see him dead than turn traitor, hence the "Father Abraham" title).

Kelly and Alexander think the whole thing has been blown, but the confrontation between father and son is just the sign the commies are looking for that the situation is for real, and they kidnap the guy (it's amazing how many one punch knockouts they have in this series!) for interrogation. To further complicate matters, Daddy comes to the rescue before the physicist can give away his "information". Kelly and Alexander have to knock out the father and return the physicist to his captors, where he can finally spill and beans, and they can finally get back to rescue him (even from his own father, who witnesses the "betrayal"). In the end, father is set straight, and the physicist is set to disappear, supposedly killed in the scuffle (but with a posthumous medal to make Dad proud).

Obviously, between this episode and the one I detailed previously, some of the writers for "I Spy" had some real Daddy issues.

The Ultraspy Version
Take out the rocket fuel angle, and make it an Ironman-like battle suit! The young guy, who is a certifiable genius, has invented a great suit of battle armor. Unfortunately, only one has ever been created, and the government has spent millions of dollars trying to create others to no avail (some kind of psychic link between the guy and the suit). The guy, feeling guilty for all of the money he's wasted and useless because he can't create any others, comes up with this plan to derail the commies in their own battle armor program.

Everything else can proceed pretty much along the same storyline, except the commies should be equipped with some high tech gear of their own, and Dad should definitely show up for his rescue in the battle suit, which could be subsequently claimed and used by the commies.

In addition to reading a lot during this brief break, I've also been watching some stuff I've had for a while on DVD. Mostly, I've been checking out "I Spy" seasons 2 and 3. It occurred to me that I could "Ultraspyify" most of these episodes to come up with some nifty adventure seeds for my "Sex, Lies and Ultraspies" roleplaying game.

One of my favorite episodes that I've seen so far is called "Little Boy Lost". It stars Opie (a young Ron Howard) as a kid neglected by his rocket scientist father (played by Napoleon Solo, aka Robert Vaugn). Opie decides to get Dad's attention by stealing a miniature guidance system and running away from home. Our two intrepid agents, Bill Cosby and Robert Culp, are assigned to find the kid and the guidance system before the Russians (or at least some vaguely Eastern European types) do. Added into the mix is a sweet hearted secretary who is a little too sweet hearted for her fellow man (she bleeds pink, if you know what I mean, and is an obvious dupe for those swarthy Eastern European types). In the end, the hip cat agents find and befriend the boy at an amusement park, beat off the communists, and retrieve the guidance system. I do like how the episode avoids syruppy sap at the end (that would have been the '80s style) as father and son still seem to have some issues.

The Ultraspy version should have the kid possess "special" powers, and I'm thinking teleportation (a la I Dream Of Jeannie) might be fun. Keep the kid hanging out at an amusement park, but add in some Paladin-types from the movie Jumpers looking to eliminate one of their own who has gone bad. Also, I'd give the commies some "special" powers of their own (I'm thinking at least a wolverine-type sniffer/tracker combat monster type). Change the setting from Malibu to the Brighton Resort area in southwest England and most of the rest of the story would be good. The only thing that doesn't ring very British is the "Poor me, my father ignores me" vibe. I suspect most upper class British children would actually expect that sort of treatment. It could easily be altered with a "I'm special, but Daddy doesn't want me to show it. I'll show him by taking away what make him special" vibe, particularly given the kid's powers.

Voila, an ultrapyified adventure awaits!

Since I'm finished with my summer classes and have yet to begin my Fall class, I've had some time to read, and I've actually made the most of it. Here's what I've gotten through so far:

On Writing by Stephen King: After running across this as a strong recommendation for the second time in as many months (the first was by Kelly Gallagher, a teacher/writer whom I greatly respect, the second was from cybersluagh), I decided to pick this up and check it out. I'm not really sure about the advice on writing (it strikes me mostly as a "this is what works for me" manual) but the autobiographical incidents from King's own life are priceless. It did make me realize that I don't want to be a novelist at this point in my life, even though I (like King) have vivid memories of the first novel I read where I thought "I can do better than this." It was Sahara by Clive Cussler. I probably read a few other stinkers before then, but no one makes as much money off from his or her crap as Cussler.

Stormbreaker by Anthony Horowitz: Speaking of crap (just kidding, sort of), I picked up a couple of the early Alex Rider series about a teenage spy. It's nice to see that my reading habits have picked up quite a bit during this break. I'm ashamed to say they've really slacked off quite a bit for the last ten or so years.

I've had a week to ponder the events of GenCon, so here goes.

I ran six events this year. I had a total of 29 players for an average of 4.83 players per event. Not bad, especially considering my Sindbad event didn't go off at all (0 players) and my Spy Racers game only had 2. They were both on Saturday, generally the busiest day of the convention, which was especially discouraging. Spy Racers also proved that an event which fills up in preregistration can be particularly problematic, as it's likely that a large group signed up together and may have found something better to do.

My general impression is that the 3 hour format I tried out this year didn't work all that well for me. I had two events go right up to the three hour mark (which in turn caused problems for the next GM at the table) and the rest all went less (some almost criminally so). It was very difficult for me to gauge pacing, as I'm much more comfortable with 4 hours. Most importantly, the 3 hour event did nothing to attract more gamers to my event. I had thought the busy gamers of GenCon might give a 3 hour event more of a try, but GenCon forces you to charge the same amount as a 4 hour event, so that really didn't happen.

So next year, I'm going to only run 4 hour events. I'm going to stay away from Saturday, which means I'll be running four events. Gone will be Qerth (which actually had a fairly decent conclusion), Sindbad (which unfortunately did not, but the only reason I wanted to run it this year was because of how awesome it was last year), and Rocket Jocks (which is a game I've discovered is very hard to keep from turning into purely ridiculous camp).

Set in stone will be three Sex, Lies and Ultraspies games: Ministry Q (which went off almost perfectly this year, except for that one "problematic" player who dwells a bit too much on a tiresome theme, Submariners (ditto, except different tiresome theme), and Racing Spies (my new name for Spy Racers).

The second lieutenant role wasn't taken (and he tends to be awfully similar to the grizzled veteran role) so I thought about changing the genders up. I tried Zale Perry from Sea Hunt (Lloyd Bridges was currently filling the role), but I couldn't find any decent photos of her in scuba gear (or at all actually). So, it's going to be Claudine Auger from Thunderball.

For my final event, I'd really like to try something reasonably "serious". I'm thinking about a "Heart of Darkness" type adventure with "Ultramercs", i.e. mercenaries in the '60s with limited paranormal abilities. I'll have to think about it a little more, but I do have at least a year to ponder it.

I picked up a copy of the Wild Talents Role-playing Game a couple of weeks ago. It's the essential edition, so it was only 10 bucks and pretty hard to pass up (not that I've passed up many super-hero role-playing games in the past).

For those who don't know, Wild Talents has a pretty funky die rolling mechanic. Its a dice pool system, meaning your stat plus your skill tells you how many dice you will be rolling. As long as two of your dice results match, you've succeeded. That's fairly straightforward, but the funky thing for Wild Talents is the number of matches tells you how fast you succeeded, while the number matched tells you how well you succeeded. There's some other added stuff to the dice rolling, but that's the basics.

I'm not sure I completely like the system, since it implies that the more skilled you are in an area, the faster you can get things done (not necessarily the higher quality work you can produce, which is mostly just a random number). It also uses 10 sided dice, which makes my inner mathematician cringe (they're not even symmetrical polyhedrons!).

Another thing I didn't like was the combat example in the book, which had a scuffle between two supposed teammates (in a bar, no less) devolve into near-death for one of them. The example also only detailed the player's rolls, with the gamemaster apparently rolling behind a screen and simply telling the results. I guess I've been rolling in front of my players and fairly applying the results for so long now that this just felt completely wrong.

I really like examples in a role-playing game book, however. So much so, I've been working on a fairly extensive one for the Vehicle Chase Rules in Sex, Lies and Ultraspies (involving 8 vehicles, no less!).

After having read the original novel, I bought and watched the "Live and Let Die" James Bond DVD the other week. Of course I've already seen it multiple times, but it brought back fond memories of how much fun Bond movies used to be.

Ever the contrarian, I've decided that Sir Roger Moore has been the best James Bond so far. Most people put him at the bottom of their list. Obviously, it helps that he was the James Bond I grew up with in the '70s and early '80s, but there's certainly other reasons I can make this claim as well.

He made the most "official" Bond movies, clocking in at 7 (which actually ties Sir Sean Connery if you count that unofficial "Never Say Never Again"). Through his run, he dutifully played the role, never complaining, quitting, coming back again, quitting again, making an unofficial one, etc. He even strongly suggested that he was getting a little long in the tooth for the last couple ("Octopussy" and "A View To A Kill") that they wanted him to do. All of his movies were considered highly successful at the box office.

Most of all, he seems to have known exactly what his Bond was all about--and that is pure fantasy escapism. "Live and Let Die", his first Bond movie, is a perfect example of this. Although dealing with potentially controversial issues (drugs and race), you never get the feeling that this movie is taking itself very seriously. I had almost completely forgotten about the southern sheriff stereotype found in this film (one of the earliest incarnation of the many which would follow). The boat chase scenes are now the stuff of legend (they actually unintentionally set a Guinness World Record with one of their boat jumps).

Because of their focus on fantasy escapism, Moore's Bond movies are still entertaining even at their worst ("A View To A Kill"). It's hard to say the same about some of the others which tried to take a more serious approach to serious issues (Timothy Dalton's "License To Kill" which also dealt with drugs, and Pierce Brosnan's "Die Another Day" which dealt with North Korea).

It seems that yet another "industry expert" is predicting the end of role-playing games. You can check out Allen Varney's article here.

It seems like every ten years or so, something new comes onto the scene that is going to kill off role-playing games forever. First, it was video games, then computer games, then collectible card games, now it's online computer games. I have no doubt role-playing games will survive now just as they did before.

I think part of the current gloom and doom is last year's release of new edition of D&D. It strikes me that this 4th edition has not been as universally accepted as the 3rd edition. I know there were plenty of people who rejected 3rd edition (hence the whole Hackmaster phenomona), but overall I thought it (especially thanks to the whole open gaming content) really propelled role-playing games into becoming more mainstream. I'll never forget when I actually went to a Barnes and Noble one Friday night after 3rd edition's release and found several groups of high school students playing D&D there.

I do feel there's a tendency to make newer editions of games more complicated (give them more "crunch" in the proper lingo). I've seen this happen to many of the games I enjoy. Champions has certainly changed edition to edition, although it still remains fairly true to its core (although rumors abound that may change with a new edition coming out soon). BESM added an incredible amount of detail from 1st to 2nd editions. Even QAGS has added some extras between its 1st and 2nd editions. 

There also tends to be a lot of people who like older rules editions better. I believe this is called the "grognard" effect, named after Napoleon's Old Guard "grumblers" always complaining about how much better things used to be "in the old days".

Through it all, games continue to thrive. Everyone thought board and war games were on their way out when Avalon Hill was purchased by Hasbro and practically ceased to exist. They now seem stronger than ever. Give it another ten years, and everyone will still be talking about how role-playing games are dying, and grognards will be talking about how great things used to be now.

In my ongoing quest to become master of all things '60s spies, I have decided that I need to collect and read all of the James Bond books (the ones by Ian Fleming at a minimum, I may waver slightly on the updated ones).

During my misspent youth, I probably read over half of the Ian Fleming books. I can easily remember Moonraker, Diamonds Are Forever, Dr. No, Goldfinger, For Your Eyes Only, Thunderball, You Only Live Twice, and The Man with the Golden Gun. That's 8 of the 14 right there. I'm a little hazy on Live And Let Die, From Russia With Love, and On Her Majesty's Secret Service. I may or may not have read these, and unlike some of the previously mentioned novels, the movies are somewhat close to the books, so that's adding to my confusion as well. I'm absolutely positive I haven't read Casino Royale, The Spy Who Loved Me, and Octopussy and the Living Daylights.

So, I've purchase Fleming's first three Bond novels (man are paperbacks insanely priced nowadays or what?) and I've finished the first one Casino Royal, and I am now well into the second one, Live and Let Die. I have to admit I enjoy Fleming's style and I can see why he practically invented the fictional espionage genre. Even in Casino Royale, where he really seems to be struggling as a new writer, there's enough decent material to keep me interested. He really picked up the pace in what I've read of Live and Let Die so far, (although he suffers from that very British form of paternalistic racism).

I also decided to check out the young Bond series. It's opening novel is called Silverfin, and I'm sorry to say that I thought it was pretty poor reading. There's absolutely nothing other than the Bond name to distinguish it from nearly any other young adult stuff. It's set in the '30s with a 13 year old Bond, which makes sense from an age perspective, but still loses a lot of the '60s feel that I'm looking for. Even worse, there's absolutely nothing distinguishing about this young James Bond other than the fact that he says "I'm Bond, James Bond" a lot. He somehow gets wrapped up in a bizarre genetic experiment (???) being conducted by an American (???) turned Scottish Lord (???). It's even worse when you're thinking like a language arts teacher and looking for things like characterization and themes. Unfortunately, it looks like there's at least four more sequels already out.
